description:
Camelina sativa, commonly known as gold-of-pleasure or false flax, is an annual oilseed plant that belongs to the Brassicaceae family. It is a close relative of other Brassica crops such as canola, mustard, and rapeseed.

Camelina sativa is a small, herbaceous plant that typically grows to a height of 30-90 cm. The leaves are narrow, oblong, and covered with fine hairs. The flowers are small, yellow, and have four petals. The plant produces small, elongated seed pods that contain numerous small, yellowish-brown seeds.

The seeds of Camelina sativa are rich in omega-3 fatty acids, particularly alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), as well as other beneficial compounds such as tocopherols and carotenoids. The oil extracted from the seeds has a unique flavor and is gaining attention as a nutritious and sustainable alternative to other vegetable oils.

Camelina sativa is considered a versatile and hardy crop, as it can grow in a wide range of soil conditions and climates, and it is relatively resistant to pests and diseases. It has been cultivated for centuries, primarily in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, and is now being explored as a potential biofuel and industrial feedstock crop in various parts of the world.
